div.head: Concerning the text
div.p:
Again it is asked Lombardus, I, d. 12, c. 1, n. 1
etc. after the Master determined about the generation of the Son and the procession of the Holy Spirit, now he treats about each of them individually by comparison, and he divides this into two parts because in the first place he inquires about the order of procession, in the second place he shows the difference between generation and spiration. The second part begins at the beginning of distinction 13, at
after these things Lombardus, I, d. 13, c. 1, n. 1
etc.

The first part is divided into two because in the first place he introduces the questions, in the second place he puts responses to these. The second begins at
these things and questions of this type Lombardus, I, d. 12, c. 1 . And this is divided into three because in the first place he shows that the Holy Spirit does not proceed from the Father earlier than the Son, in the second place that he does not proceed more fully from one than the other, in the third place he explains the understanding of some authorities in a different sense. The second begins at
but now it should be treated Lombardus, I, d. 12, c. 2 . The third begins at
Augustine nevertheless Lombardus, I, d. 12, c. 2 .

Then follows distinction 13
after this Lombardus, I, d. 13, c. 1
etc., which is divided into two parts because in the first place he shows in what mode the Spirit is not able to be said to be begotten, in the second place in what sense it is not able to be said to be unbegotten. The second begins at
now it should be considered Lombardus, I, d. 13, c. 4, n. 1 .

The first part is divided in three because in the first place he shows how to be generated does not suit the Holy Spirit, in the second place that to proceed applies to the Son, in the third place that between generation and procession there is a difference or distinction. The second starts
But when the Holy Spirit Lombardus, I, d. 13, c. 2 . But the third starts at
among the generation of the Son Lombardus, I, d. 13, c. 3, n. 1 .

The second principal part is divided into three because in the first place he shows that the Holy Spirit ought not to be called begotten, in the second place from the words of Jerome he makes an objection to the contrary, and in the third place he solves the argument of the objection. The second begins at
nevertheless Jerome Lombardus, I, d. 13, c. 4, n. 5 . And the third at
but as this Lombardus, I, d. 13, c. 4, n. 7
etc. And this is the division of these distinctions, etc.

div.head: Quaestio
div.p: Whether it is possible that the Holy Spirit was produced is neither begotten nor unbegotten, whether the Holy Spirit proceeds from the Father and Son in such a way that faith concedes that it is neither unbegotten or begotten, whether the Holy Spirit is produced in such a way from the Father and the Son that he is neither begotten nor unbegotten.

div.head: Rationes principales
div.p:
It truly seems that this is not the case because, if the Holy Spirit were not begotten, it would follow that the pilgrim theologian would be able to know the difference or the distinction between generation and procession. The consequence is valid and the falsity of the consequent is clear through
Augustine
and the Master in the text of his 13th distinction saying:
between generation and procession, while we live here, we are not able to distinguish Lombard, I, d. 13, c. 3, n. 1 .

In the second place, the internal productions of the divine are of the same reasons and species, therefore just as the Son through one is said to be begotten, so the Holy Spirit for a similarity in species is able to be called begotten. The consequence is clear because specific identity of production and of producing and the produced terms argue sufficiently for the identity of the denomination or of the natural properties, otherwise it would be the case that the production of Socrates and Plato would be of the same species, and nevertheless one would be of the same species and the other would not. The antecedent is first proved because the terms or persons produced through these productions do not differ in species, but only numerically or personally.

In the third place, the Holy Spirit is and is not begotten, therefore it is unbegotten, The consequence is clear because the negative
infers one affirmative about a negated predicate and a proposition about negated predicate infers one about an infinite or infinitated predicate, therefore etc.

In opposition is the
Master in this distinction 13
Lombardus, I, d. 13, XXX
and
Augustine, in book 1 De Trinitate, chapter 6
Augustinus, De Trinitate, I, XXX .

div.head: Prima conclusio
div.p:
The first conclusion: though it is impossible that the production of the Son is not distinguished from the production of the Holy Spirit, nevertheless from the common law in the present life no one is able to know this distinction with evident reason. The first is proved because otherwise it would be possible that there is in the divine which now de facto is, if these productions were not distinguished. But this is impossible, therefore. The impossibility is clear through what is said above because in whatever way the divine is internally, it is necessarily that way. The second part is clear through the
Master, in this distinction XXX . Again through Augustine XIII De Trinitate, chapter 13 saying that
we will see the Trinity in this light where no reason will be Augustinus, De Trinitate, XIII, c. 13, xxx . And the entire conclusion confirmed through
Damascene, in book 1, chapter 10
saying
in someway we say there is a difference between generation and procession Damascenus, De fide orthodoxa, I, c. 10 . But what mode of difference this is are in no way for this and also the conclusion words in the text of the Master. .

The first corollary: in which
it does not follow evidently that the the Son is produced only by the Father and that the Holy Spirit is produced by both, therefore the generation of the Son is distinguished from the procession of the Holy Spirit. This is clear because the unity or plurality of the one's producing does not imply the plurality or distinction of the productions, most especially where there is one mode of acting, as is the case in what has been proposed, as it was said above.

The second corollary: that in the same way it does not follow, produced supposites are plurified distinctly, therefore the productions of the same are in some way distinguished. This is clear from the same.

Third corollary: that from the mode of producing such a distinct is not able to be evidently shown. This is clear because, if the mode of proceeding sufficed, then this would be, therefore because the Son proceeds as born and the Holy Spirit as given, as says
Augustine V De Trinitate, chapter 14 . But this argument does not show why the Holy Spirit does not proceed as born, therefore it does not suffice. From what has been said it would be able to be inferred that something is a necessary being which no pilgrim under the current law is able to know. This is clear from the distinction of the production of the persons.

div.head: Second Conclusion
div.p:
Second conclusion: a specific distinction between the divine persons is as repugnant as the same distinction between eternal productions. This is proved because it is repugnant in both cases, therefore it is equally repugnant. The consequences is clear because the repugnance or the opposition of a contradiction does not have latitude nor can it be more or less when taken in the same way. The antecedent is proved because every specific distinction argues and implies diversity of nature. But such diversity is repugnant to the divine essence, therefore a specific distinction in the divine persons or productions should not be asserted. The second part is proved because productions are not distinct unless by reason of a distinction of the persons or because it terminates in distinct persons. But the persons are not distinguished in species but only in number, therefore. In the second place, the conclusion is proved because the divine supposites are absolutely of the same perfection, therefore they are of the same species. The consequence holds because, just as no two species are of the same perfection, so etc. The antecedent is catholic. In the third place, it is confirmed through Damascene, in book III, chapter 6
saying:
we say the hypostases differ in number and not in species or in nature
Damascenus, De fide orthodoxa 3, 6 (Buytaert, 186, ll. 9-10)
, therefore.

The first corollary: but the divine supposites and internal productions are not distinguished specifically, it is conceded catholically that they are distinguished in number. This is clear through what has been said.

Second corollary: it does not follow a is produced through generation and b is not produced through generation, therefore a is specifically distinguished from b. This is clear because the Son and Holy Spirit are not distinguished specifically, and nevertheless the Son is generated and the Holy Spirit is not.

Third corollary: though in the divine there are three supposites distinct in number, nevertheless they are not properly called three individuals of the same species, This corollary is asserted by
Thomas of Argentina, in book 1, distinction 13
Thomas of Strasbourg, XXX
saying it is not able to be because individual conveys a difference of nature, but not a supposite.

div.head: Third Conclusion
div.p:
Third conclusion: just it is not the case that the Holy Spirit is the Father or the Son, so it is repugnant that the Holy Spirit is begotten or not begotten. The first part is proved because the divine persons are necessarily distinguished, therefore. The consequence is clear and the antecedent is proved because, if it were not, there would be a confusion of persons in the divine or there would only be one, each is an error and impossible, therefore. The second part is proved because to be begotten is to be the Son and to be unbegotten is to be the Father, therefore etc. The antecedent is clear in distinction 13 in distinction 13 where he says that
if the Holy Spirit were begotten, there would be two sons in the divine, and if he were unbegotten, we would put two fathers in the trinity Augustinus, Ad Orosium, q. 2 (PL 40:734) Cf. Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 13, c. 4 , just as Augustine says, therefore.

The first corollary: just as the alterity of persons is through natural identity, so the duality of the productions is through triune personality. This is proved because in the divine there are only two productions, namely generation and procession.

The second corollary: just as the Father alone is produced by nothing, so the Father alone is properly called unbegotten. This is clear through what has been said. Again through the
Damascene, in book one, chapter nine , saying
only the Father is unbegotten, only the Son is begotten, only the Holy Spirit is processible or proceeding. Damescenus, De Fide Orthodoxa, I, c. 9 .

Third corollary: though the Holy Spirit is able to be called unbegotten improperly and negatively,
nevertheless it ought not to be called unbegotten properly or privitively. The first part is clear because the Holy Spirit is not begotten, therefore it is unbegotten, when understanding unbegotten negatively. The second part is clear through what has been said because then the person of the Holy Spirit would be the person of the Father, which is impossible. From everything else the affirmative part of the conclusion follows.

div.head: Objections
div.p:
Against the first conclusion, it is argued in the first place with the arguments of
Hugolinus against Gregory arguing in the first book, in distinction 10 up to distinction 14 Hugolinus, XXX
because the Son is from one, the Holy Spirit from two, therefore from the mode of proceeding between generation and procession there is able to be a distinction. But Master Gregory says that this does not suffice, therefore Hugolinus replies in opposition where there is production of the Word a double producing or productive thing is not required, therefore the ratio of distinction between generation and procession is able to be assigned. The antecedent is clear because one producing thing is sufficient.

In the second place, where there is generation of a living person, there is not able to be several generating, unless one of them were disposed in the mode of a mother, but this is impossible in the divine, therefore.
In the third place, where a person is omnipotent and speaks itself, if another person is required, it follows either that it is not omnipotent or produces in another mode than by speaking, therefore.

In the fourth place against the third corollary, since, though the Holy Spirit is knowledge, nevertheless it is not knowledge through process, nor is the Son love by generation. Therefore these productions are sufficiently distinguished given that the Son is not love through generation and nor does the Holy Spirit have what is knowledge through spiration. See
Hugolinus, book I, distinction 10 and 11, article 4
Hugolinus, I, d. 10 et 11, a. 4 , where he argues against Gregory.

In the fifth place, ever perfect operation terminates in some produced terminus. But it possible to conclude by reason that in God there is the perfect operation of intellect and will, therefore it is possible to conclude that divine understanding terminates int he Word and the divine will terminates in love. But when nothing produces itself, it follows that what is produced really differs from what is producing. But such a difference is not able to be in the essence, therefore it must be in the persons and their processions.

In the sixth place, that created nature is found in many supposites is a type of perfection in creatures absolutely, therefore it should be attributed to the divine nature. The consequence holds because whatever is a kind of perfection in creatures ought to be attributed to God.

Against the second conclusion, the production of divine persons is according forms distinct in species, therefore such productions are distinguished in species. The consequence is clear because a distinction is specific which is according to distinct forms. And the antecedent is clear because divine relations are distinct in species, namely paternity, filiation, and passive spiration, and through things the divine supposites are distinguished, therefore.

In the second place, the divine supposites, having been made distinct through these things, are not able to give a distinction other than this which suits them according to their formal ratio. But paternity and filiation differ in species according to their formal rationes, therefore these things which make them distinct are distinguished in species.

In the third place against the corollaries, in the three divine persons there is not a greater goodness than in one, therefore three persons are posited in vain, therefore this should not be posited. This consequence is clear because
God and nature do nothing in vain
Aristoteles, De caelo, I (XXX)
as is said in
book I On the heavens , and the antecedent is catholic.

In the fourth place, just as the highest good is disposed to evil, so the highest one is disposed to a multitude. But it is repugnant for there to be evil in the highest good, therefore it is repugnant for there to be a multitude in the highest one. Therefore, just as sin or the ability to sin is repugnant to God, so is a plurality of persons.

In the fifth place, every relative real opposition goes out to two extremes which are really distinguished. Therefore either it is necessary to posit one relative opposition in the divine or two. If one, then there will only be two extremes, If two, then there will be four extremes, and as a consequence there will be four persons, which should not be said.

In the sixth place, it is the same thing to say the Father speaks himself as it is to say he generates the Word. But the Son and the Holy Spirit perfectly speak themselves or understand just as the Father, therefore either three words are said or none.

In the seventh place, the Father by loving the Son, and the Son by loving the Father back produce the Holy Spirit. But the Father does not love the Holy Spirit less than the Son, nor is loved less in return by the Holy Spirit than by the Son, therefore the Father and the Holy Spirit produce another Holy Spirit or
no person is produced through love.

Against the third conclusion and corollaries, it is argued in the first place through Jerome who is quoted by the
Master in distinction 11
Lombard, Sent. I, d. 13, c. 4
, saying
The Holy Spirit is not the Father, but is unbegotten, nevertheless he is not the Father because he is of the Father Hieronymus, Regulis definitionum, XXX , therefore the Holy Spirit is unbegotten.

Against the first corollary, there is a single mode of communicating nature, as says the Commentator VIII of the Physics . But through some internal production nature is communicated, therefore there will only be one production.

In the third place, between the generation and the procession there is no relative opposition, therefore there is no distinction. The consequence holds because all things are the same where there is no opposition of relation. And the antecedent is proved because everything that is generated proceeds although the converse is not true, therefore.

div.head: Responses
div.p: To the first, what is assumed is denied universally because the word of our mind according to being proceeds both from the mind and from an object. In the second place, I say that, having supposed that the one producing is sufficient, if nevertheless there are two, the Word does not fail to proceed.

To the second, the antecedent taken universally would be able to be denied because some mode of generation of all living things is not known to us. In the second place, I say that this only has truth in those things which concur materially for the generation of what is produced, and thus does not apply to the Father and the Son with respect to the Holy Spirit because they equally spirate the Holy Spirit. In the third place, the argument is redirected against the one making it in no production of the living from the living are there able to be several things producing unless there is one, etc. But the production of the holy Spirit is a production of the living from the living, therefore the Son takes the place of a mother.

To the third, it is said that the antecedent does not have greater truth with respect to speaking than it does with respect to loving. For it is the case the Father while loving himself is omnipotent, and nevertheless the Son, who loves himself, is required for the production of the Holy Spirit.
In the second place, it is said that one divine person does not properly require another, as this word suggest a lack or imperfection.

In the third place, I say that, according to the objector himself, the consequence is not valid. For the production of b many persons are required, therefore neither is omnipotent, for in
distinction 7
he says this consequence is not valid a is of so much potency that it suffices alone to produce b, and a alone is not able to produce creature d, therefore a greater potency is required for producing d than b.

To the fourth, it is said that the argument begs the question because, when the Holy Spirit proceeds and the same nature through procession, each equally communicates perfectly why one production does not speak the other. Therefore, that the Son is not love through generation, etc. is to manifest the same thing through same thing or more greatly known through the less known.

To another, the adversary would say that this does not have truth in immanent operations, just willing and understanding are internal, whence in book IX of the Metaphysics
and
book I of the Physics
it is said that through immanent operations nothing is constituted, otherwise it be equally proved that the Holy Spirit produces internally.

To the sixth, the antecedent is denied because a spiritual nature not multiplied in many supposites is more perfect than a material and corruptible thing which is multiplied through individual supposites.

To the first against the second conclusion, in the first place the antecedent is denied because, just as the Father is not distinguished in species from the Son, so the Son is not distinguished from paternity because the 'by the Son' and the Son are the same. In the second place, it would be possible to be said that, granted that paternity and filiation were specifically distinguished considered unto themselves, nevertheless, as they constitute divine supposites, they have the mode of individual properties. But because I do not say that they are constituted as persons through these properties, therefore I stand with the first solution and reject the second which is the solution of
Thomas of Strasbourg
XXX .

To the second, it is said that the major premise does not have truth with respect to those things which give individual and incommunicable being, as is the case here. But it holds with respect to the divine principles which being distinct in and of themselves give being absolutely.
To the third, the consequence is denied because this goodness is there in many modes.

To the fourth, the major premise passes, but when it is further said that to God
or to the divine essence, which thus is the good in the highest way, plurification is as repugnant as sin and condemnation, this is conceded, but nevertheless with its unity the plurality of persons is perfectly compatible.

To the fifth, it is said that in the divine there are only two opposite relations. For the first we have the Father and the Son. Fro the second we have the Holy Spirit because the second of the extremes of the dua relations does not constitute a person, namely the active spiration which is common to the Father and the Son.

To the sixth, it is said that, though evident reason is not able to be assigned apart from faith why the speaking or understanding of the Son does not terminate in some produced term, nevertheless with the supposition of faith t is able to be said that to speak is able to be taken in two ways. In one way properly which is the same as conceiving the word, and
Augustine V De Trinitate
Augustinus, De Trinitate, V, XXX
takes it this way when he says that
non singulus in divinis sed Pater est dicens Augustinus, De Trinitate, VII, c. 1 . And in this way the major of the argument is conceded and the minor o the second part of the antecedent is denied. To say is taken in a second mode when it is meant to understand perfectly, and in this way the minor ought to be understood. And in this case, note that the conclusion does not follow because medium is changed. In the second place, it would be able to be said that non only is he able to produce perfectly in virtue of the fact that he understand perfectly precisely, but also because the perfect understanding is in the Father himself with inclusion of the required relation for the producing the son which relation is paternity, but the Son and the Holy Spirit, though they understand, nevertheless they do not have a relation, therefore they do not generate through understanding. But in saying it this way it is to solve the same thing through the same thing.

To the seventh, it is said, just as before, that it does not follow, for though the Holy Spirit equally perfectly loves in addition to the Father and the Son, nevertheless it does not have this with the relation necessarily required for producing the Holy Spirit, which is active spiration which is opposed to passive spiration which the Holy Spirit has or is.

To the first against the third conclusion it is said to Jerome that unbegotten is able to be taken in three ways. In the first place, for that which does not have generation in itself understood passively, In the second place, for that which does not have the generation of this thing. In the third place, for that which does not have generation and nor is from something having it, and with this has a property in opposition to passive generation. In the first mode, the Holy Spirit is said to be unbegotten because it is not begotten and it is in this mode that Jerome speaks. In the second mode, the divine essence is said to unbegotten. In the third mode, only the Father is unbegotten and, and it is in this mode that the conclusion is meant.
To the second it is said that the Commentator speaks about the communication of the created nature.

To the third, it is said in the first mode that the argument is founded on something false. In the first place, because persons are not only distinguished by opposing relations. In the second place, because the productions of the divine differ from themselves and not only in relations, therefore the argument does not conclude.
To the first argument in the opposition, it is clear through what is said in the first conclusion because it does not follow that the pilgrim is able to know, even though it is the case.
To the second, the consequence is denied.

To the third, it is clear from the third conclusion and the solution of the arguments against it because the Holy Spirit is able to be called unbegotten and improperly according to the first mode of the distinction posited. In the second mode, it would be possible this consequence
that is not begotten, therefore it is unbegotten is denied, just as it does not follow that
this is not just, therefore it is unjust
because this can be said about a stone. The antecedent is true and the consequent is false.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Again when it is asked Lombardus, I, d. 12, c. 1, n. 1 . This distinction contains three conclusions. First: that when it is asked whether the Holy Spirit proceeds from the Father earlier than from the Son, it should be said that whoever is able to understand the generation of the Son from the Father without time also understands that the procession of the Holy Spirit from both the Father and the Son is without time because in the Trinity nothing is before or after because there nothing begins from time.
Second conclusio: that just as the Holy Spirit did not proceed from the Father before the Son, so he does not proceed from the Father more greatly or more amply or more fully that from the Son.

Third conclusion: that when Augustine says that
the Holy Spirit proceeds from the Father principally Augustinus, De Trinitate, XV, 26, 47 (XXX)
and Jerome says that
he proceeds from the Father properly Hieronymus, Ad Cyrillum, Epist. 17, c. 1 et 3 (PL 30:176)
and Hilary says that
the Holy Spirit is sent from the Father through the Son and from the Father and has its being from the Father through the Son
XXX , ought to be understood in such a way that because the Holy
Spirit proceeds from the Father he has this from the Father himself but because he proceeds from the Son or is sent from him the Son has this from the Father because the Father by generating the Son gives to it that which the Holy Spirit proceeds from and is sent from.

After this it should be considered Lombardus, I, d. 13, c. 1, n. 1 . Distinction 13 contains seven conclusion First: that though the Holy Spirit proceeds from the Father and is from the substance of the Father, just as the Son is, nevertheless he is not said to be born or begotten, and therefore it is not called the son, the reason for which is because, if it were called the Son, then it would be the Son of the Father when it proceeds from Both. But it is absurd that it is the Son of both because nothing is the Son of two things unless of a father and mother.

Second conclusion: that though the Son and the Holy Spirit proceed from the Father, nevertheless they do so differently because the Holy Spirit proceeds from the Father in the mode of a gift or as a gift, but the Son proceeds as born as or as begotten, and therefore the Holy Spirit is not the Son

Third conclusion: that the Holy Spirit is not called the Son because it is not begotten just as something unbegotten nor is it made as something would be born through the grace of God in adoption, just as we are also, and thus it would be said to be the Son of God through adoption.
Fourth conclusion: that it is not the case that it was born because it proceeds, although everything that is born proceeds

Fifth conclusion: that we are not able in this life to sufficiently distinguish between the generation of the Word and the procession of the Holy Spirit, and therefore it suffices for everyone to know that the Son is not from himself, but from the Father, and nor is the Holy Spirit from himself, but proceeds from both.

Sixth conclusion: that according to Augustine, the Holy Spirit ought not to be called begotten nor unbegotten because, if he were begotten, then there would be two sons in the divine. but if it were unbegotten, then we would affirm that there are two fathers, which is inconvenient. This is clear because to be unbegotten properly belongs to the Father.

Seventh conclusion: that according to Ieromium the Holy Spirit is said to be unbegotten, but Jerome understands the word unbegotten for that which is not begotten, and in this way it is possible to conceded that the Holy Spirit is unbegotten, that is not begotten. But Augustine understands unbegotten for that which is not from another, and yet is other than something, and thus by taking unbegotten in this way it is said of the Father alone because the Son is from another and the Holy Spirit is from the Father and the Son who are different persons. And thus the Master agrees with the saying of Augustine and Jerome. And these things suffice for the present lecture.
